topics.title: Cold open: Steve Jobs elevator lore
topics.summary: Camille shares Apple lore about Steve Jobs quizzing employees in elevators and a story of someone panicking and trying to escape the elevator to avoid being questioned.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the podcast and Camille Hearst’s background (Spotify, Patreon, YouTube, iTunes, founder) and previews creator-economy topics they’ll cover.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Merge and Coda.

topics.title: Spotify fan monetization: merch and listening parties
topics.summary: Camille explains her role leading fan monetization at Spotify, focusing on helping artists convert fan passion into revenue via merch, rewards, and experiments like listening parties.

topics.title: Working with artists: creativity and charging fans
topics.summary: They discuss the joys of working with creative people and the challenge of the “starving artist” ethos—musicians often resist monetization despite fans’ willingness to pay.

topics.title: Creator monetization psychology and the content hamster wheel
topics.summary: Camille and Lenny talk about creators’ discomfort pricing their work, why platforms help with payments/pricing, and the downside of subscription models: nonstop creation with no easy exit.

topics.title: Where the creator economy is headed
topics.summary: Camille argues creator trends are real and durable despite startup shakeouts, citing platform network effects, Twitch/TikTok scale, and creators becoming IP engines like “mini Disney.”

topics.title: How creators succeed: consistency, collaboration, curation
topics.summary: Camille shares creator success patterns she’s seen since early YouTube: predictable output, collaborating to cross-pollinate audiences, and leveraging trusted curators/influencers.

topics.title: Kit startup story and selling to Patreon
topics.summary: Camille explains Kit’s curation/recommendation concept, fundraising journey, and why selling to Patreon made sense; she also reflects on lessons from building as an underrepresented founder.

topics.title: Acquisition lessons: run a process, build relationships early
topics.summary: They discuss the realities of M&A: treat selling like a managed funnel, and cultivate potential acquirers long before you need them so the relationship and vision are already familiar.

topics.title: Marketplace supply-side focus and why it matters
topics.summary: Camille describes why she’s drawn to the supply side of marketplaces, with lessons from ride-hailing (Hailo) showing that without healthy supply, demand and UX don’t matter.

topics.title: Apple and iTunes: early days and Steve Jobs encounter
topics.summary: Camille recounts being an early iTunes PMM, the famous Stanford commencement speech, meeting Jobs on her first day, and the detailed work behind iTunes press demos.

topics.title: Apple product model vs modern product management
topics.summary: Camille contrasts Apple’s design/engineering-led, craft-first approach with metric/strategy-heavy product management elsewhere, and reacts to Airbnb adopting an Apple-like model.

topics.title: Advice for new creator platforms: solve core problems
topics.summary: Camille advises founders to focus on real creator pain points—especially audience growth and getting paid—while noting adjacent needs like financing and benefits remain unsolved.

topics.title: Quick tangent: breakout podcasters and discovery
topics.summary: Lenny asks about a fast-rising podcaster; Camille notes she’s primarily a music listener and doesn’t follow podcasts closely.
